meta.title: awesome-slash
meta.description: Production-ready skills, agents, and commands for Claude Code, OpenCode, and Codex CLI. 12 plugins that automate the entire AI development workflow, not just the coding.
meta.author: Avi Fenesh

hero.title: Automate the entire workflow, not just the coding
hero.subtitle: AI models can write code. That's not the hard part anymore. The hard part is everything else -- picking tasks, managing branches, reviewing output, handling CI, addressing comments, deploying. awesome-slash automates all of it.

problem.title: The bottleneck isn't code generation
problem.description: Frontier models write good code. That's solved. What's not solved is context management, compaction amnesia, task drift, skipped steps, token waste, babysitting, and repetitive requests. You shouldn't have to orchestrate each phase manually, every single session.
points: Context management -- models forget what they're doing mid-session
Compaction amnesia -- long sessions get summarized, losing critical state
Task drift -- without structure, agents wander from the actual goal
Skipped steps -- agents skip reviews, tests, or cleanup when not enforced
Token waste -- using LLM calls for work that static analysis can do faster
Babysitting -- manually orchestrating each phase of development
Repetitive requests -- asking for the same workflow every single session

approach.title: Code does code work. AI does AI work.
approach.description: Detection uses regex, AST analysis, and static analysis -- fast, deterministic, no tokens wasted. Judgment uses LLM calls for synthesis, planning, and review -- where reasoning matters. Result: 77% fewer tokens for drift-detect vs multi-agent approaches.

commands.name: /next-task
commands.description: 12-phase workflow: discovers tasks, explores codebase, plans implementation, writes code, reviews, and ships. One plan approval unlocks autonomous execution through to merged PR.

commands.name: /agnix
commands.tagline: Lint agent configs before they break
commands.description: 155 validation rules (57 auto-fixable) for Skills, Memory, Hooks, MCP, and Plugins across 10+ AI tools including Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot, Codex CLI, OpenCode, and Gemini CLI. SARIF output for GitHub Code Scanning.

commands.name: /ship
commands.tagline: Branch to merged PR in one command
commands.description: Commits, pushes, creates PR, monitors CI, waits for auto-reviewers, addresses every comment, merges, deploys, and cleans up. Platform auto-detection for GitHub Actions, Railway, Vercel, and more.

commands.name: /deslop
commands.tagline: Kill AI slop before it ships
commands.description: 3-phase detection pipeline finds debug statements, placeholder text, verbose comments, TODOs, and over-engineering patterns. Certainty-graded findings across JS/TS, Python, Rust, Go, Java.

commands.name: /perf
commands.description: 10-phase methodology with baselines, breaking point analysis, hypothesis generation, profiling, and controlled experiments. Based on recorded real investigation sessions.

commands.name: /drift-detect
commands.tagline: Find what's documented but not built
commands.description: AST-based plan vs code analysis. JavaScript collectors gather data fast, one Opus call does semantic matching. Tested on 1,000+ repositories. 77% token reduction vs multi-agent approaches.

commands.name: /audit-project
commands.tagline: Multi-agent code review that iterates until clean
commands.description: Up to 10 specialized agents (security, performance, architecture, database, API, frontend, backend, DevOps) run based on your project. Iterates until zero open issues remain.

commands.name: /enhance
commands.tagline: Analyze everything that shapes agent behavior
commands.description: Seven parallel analyzers check your prompts, agents, plugins, docs, hooks, and skills. Certainty-graded findings with auto-fix support. Auto-learns false positives over time.

commands.name: /repo-map
commands.description: Builds a cached map of exports, functions, classes, and imports via ast-grep. Tools like drift-detect and planners use it instead of re-scanning the repo every time.

commands.name: /sync-docs
commands.tagline: Keep docs in sync with code
commands.description: Finds outdated references, stale examples, missing CHANGELOG entries, and version mismatches. Auto-fixes safe issues like version numbers and CHANGELOG entries.

commands.name: /learn
commands.tagline: Research any topic, build a learning guide
commands.description: Progressive discovery gathers 10-40 online sources, scores them by quality, and synthesizes a structured guide with RAG index. Creates reusable knowledge in agent-knowledge/.

philosophy.title: One agent, one job, done extremely well
philosophy.description: Same principle as good code: single responsibility. The exploration-agent explores. The implementation-agent implements. Specialized agents with narrow scope and clear success criteria.

philosophy.title: Pipeline with gates, not a monolith
philosophy.description: Same principle as DevOps. Each step must pass before the next begins. Can't push before review. Can't merge before CI passes. Hooks enforce this -- agents cannot skip phases.

philosophy.title: Tools do tool work, agents do agent work
philosophy.description: If static analysis, regex, or a shell command can do it, don't ask an LLM. Pattern detection uses pre-indexed regex. File discovery uses glob. The LLM only handles what requires judgment.

philosophy.title: Right model for the task
philosophy.description: Opus for complex reasoning and analysis. Sonnet for pattern matching and validation. Haiku for mechanical execution. Quality compounds -- early phases deserve the best model.

philosophy.title: Validate plan and results, not every step
philosophy.description: Approve the plan. See the results. The middle is automated. One plan approval unlocks autonomous execution through implementation, review, cleanup, and shipping.

philosophy.title: Composable, not monolithic
philosophy.description: Every command works standalone. /deslop cleans code without /next-task. /ship merges PRs without the full workflow. Pieces compose together, but each piece is useful on its own.
